Event.EventDescription: Join us for a Sydney Science Festival event as Mark Dadds from the Sydney Child Behaviour Research Clinic shares the current scientific evidence behind the building blocks of evidence-based parenting interventions: including rewards, punishment, and attachment.

Event.EventName: Sydney Science Festival - Diabetes, Heart Disease, Obesity: a looming healthcare crisis?
Event.EventDescription: Despite great improvements in treatments and More Australians are developing diseases like type 2 Diabetes, heart disease, kidney disease and liver disease. The risks increase substantially with obesity and lack of exercise. For Sydney Science Festival we discuss this healthcare crisis.

Venue.VenueStreetName: Westmead Institute for Medical Research 176 Hawkesbury Road

Event.EventName: Sydney Science Festival - Professor Kristen Hawkes on Grandmothers and Human Evolution
Event.EventDescription: Professor Kristen Hawkes, distinguished Professor of Anthropology at the University of Utah presents her work on the ‘Grandmother Hypothesis’, to explain why increased longevity evolved in humans, while female fertility still ends at the same age it does in our evolutionary cousins, the great apes.

Geoscience Australia’s 2016 annual Open Day offers a diverse program of free hands-on activities, science displays, talks and fun for all ages! Come along and learn about the exciting and important work carried out by Australia’s national geoscience agency.

Event.EventPayment: $65 per person for EQ staff (no GST); $72 per person for non EQ attendees & independent schools + GST. Includes: canapés, two course dinner and tea & coffee.

Event.EventDescription: Would you say you are literate if you could read but could not write? So how about software? Coding for kids is on the rise: Learn to Code; CoderDojo; Hour of Code; Code Club; Code Rangers; Code Camp; Code Academy. Why? Join us for a keynote address and forum: Coding is the next layer of literacy.

Event.EventName: Movie Screening of Code: Debugging The Gender Gap
Event.EventDescription: This movie screening of the documentary Code: Debugging the Gender Gap examines the reasons why more girls and people of color are not seeking opportunities in computer science and explores how cultural mindsets, stereotypes, educational hurdles and sexism all play roles in this national crisis. Apercentage of the admission fees will go towards supporting techtrails, a STEM career incursion into WA High Schools, an initiative of Women in Technology WA (WiTWA).
Event.EventPayment: $20 per person.

Event.EventDescription: Wiradjuri Elder Michael Lyons will hold a special after-school workshop teaching students how to use the Bull-roarer. These amazing Wiradjuri instruments were vital for communication and ceremony, but there's more to them than meets the eye.

Our community day will celebrate and showcase Aboriginal sciences through a range of hands-on activities, and link them to contemporary sciences. Activities include: Traditional Nyoongar tool making, boomerang throwing, bush tucker and bush medicine, basket weaving, finger printing, amazing polymorph, using microscopes, rockets and robots. This is a free event, suitable for all ages, free sausage sizzle.

Event.EventName: Exploring plant barcoding in Kings Park
Event.EventDescription: Dr Ellen Jorgensen will present a fascinating science seminar about her challenge to barcode native plant species in an area of Alaska. Join us for this free seminar and hear Ellen's fascinating story when she visits Perth for National Science Week 2016.

All abilities challenges at Discovery this National Science Week. Tinkering, playing with things to solve problems and making workshops, we're hands on at Discovery. Come and rise to the challenge during National Science Week.
Event.EventPayment: Access to our National Science Week programmes will be included in our regular pricing.

Event.EventDescription: Get up close and personal with the invisible world, invisible to the naked eye that is! Join microscopist, John Harper from Charles Sturt University and students from the Faculty of Science to discover everyday things that you won’t see everyday – without a microscope!

Roxby’s Mad Scientists is a fun, hands-on event held during National Science Week. The event is free for all to attend (children under 10 years of age will require parental supervision) and will incorporate physical, chemical, biological, earth and technological sciences.

How do you create an image of something that you cannot see? This exhibition is a collaboration between a marine spatial analyst and two visual artists who each use the image as a primary means of translating the marine environment. Floor Talk at 2.30pm, Fri 19 August.

Event.EventDescription: A display at the Dubbo Sustainable City Expo & Science Festival. What is the oldest thing you have ever held? Event.EventName: Aboriginal science for little ones - Griffith Library
Event.EventDescription: Larry Brandy Aboriginal storyteller will be a special guest at preschool storytime at the Griffith Library. Children will become emus, kangaroos and hunters as they learn how Aboriginal people use their knowledge of plants and animals to hunt and find food.

Event.EventDescription: Larry Brandy Aboriginal storyteller will be a special guest at preschool storytime at the Albury Library and Museum. Children will become emus, kangaroos and hunters as they learn how Aboriginal people use their knowledge of plants and animals to hunt and find food.

Event.EventName: The Tactile Reef - Putting the spotlight on global warming and coral bleaching
Event.EventDescription: Territory Wildlife Park will be showcasing a Tactile Reef made of crocheted, knitted and needle-felted corals and marine animals that visitors can touch and interact with. Our Park guides will talk to visitors about the crochet project and explain what is happening to our reef systems.
Event.EventPayment: Standard entry fee will be charged to visit the Park, there is no charge to see the Tactile Reef once the Park entry fee has been paid. Visit website to get more information on entry fees to the Park.
